cyclone.name: IRMA
cyclone.current_location: lingering over the north coast of Cuba
cyclone.trajectory: expected to turn northwest later today and then north-northwest on Sunday, tracking up the Florida peninsula and then into Georgia/Tennessee
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida Keys during the pre-dawn hours of 2017-09-10, then a second landfall along the southwest coast of Florida Sunday afternoon

weather_observation.under_watch: Storm Surge Watch (north of port), Hurricane Watch (north of Fernandina Beach), but PORT itself is in warning area
weather_observation.under_warning: Hurricane Warning and Storm Surge Warning
weather_observation.watch_coast: Storm Surge Watch from north of the Volusia/Brevard County line to Isle of Palms, SC
weather_observation.warning_coast: Hurricane Warning from Fernandina Beach southward around the Florida peninsula to the Aucilla River; Storm Surge Warning from the Volusia/Brevard County line southward around the peninsula to the Suwanee River
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida east coast south of Fernandina Beach, including Brevard County and Port Canaveral; strongest core projected for the Keys and west coast but dangerous conditions extend well outward
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds are likely (84% chance) with a 31% chance of sustained 50-kt winds; brief hurricane-force gusts possible as Irma passes inland to the west.
weather_observation.storm_surge: 2–4 ft of surge possible along the Brevard coast, including Port Canaveral, per NHC surge table (Storm Surge Warning in effect).
weather_observation.rainfall: 8–15 inches of rain possible across the Florida peninsula with isolated 20 inch totals; Port Canaveral could easily exceed 4 inches and experience flash flooding.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Dangerous rip currents, large surf, and the potential for isolated tornadoes in outer rain bands may disrupt port operations.
